root.para: When an entity has relatively few transactions involving financial instruments, it may be relatively easy for the auditor to obtain an understanding of the entityâ€™s objectives for using the financial instruments and the characteristics of the instruments. In such circumstances, much of the audit evidence is likely to be substantive in nature; the auditor may perform the majority of the audit work at year-end; and third-party confirmations are likely to provide evidence in relation to the completeness, accuracy, and existence of the transactions.
